[[Autism spectrum]] disorder (ASD) includes [[autism]], [[Asperger disorder]], [[childhood disintegrative disorder]] and [[pervasive developmental disorder not otherwise specified]]. While the exact cause of ASD has remained somewhat of a mystery, it appears to be genetic in origin.<ref name="Schanen">{{cite journal|title=Epigenetics of autism spectrum disorders|journal=Human Molecular Genetics|volume=15|pages=R138–R150|date=2006|author=Schanen N. C.|doi=10.1093/hmg/ddl213|pmid=16987877|doi-access=free}}</ref> Most data supports a [[polygenic]], [[epistatic]] model, meaning that the disorder is caused by two or more genes and that those genes are interacting in a complex manner. Several genes, between two and fifteen in number, have been identified and could potentially contribute to disease susceptibility.<ref name="Pickles"/><ref name="Risch">{{cite journal |author=Risch N |author2=Spiker D |author3=Lotspeich L |title=A genomic screen of autism: evidence for a multilocus etiology |journal=American Journal of Human Genetics |volume=65 |issue=2 |pages=493–507 |date=August 1999 |pmid=10417292 |pmc=1377948 |doi=10.1086/302497 |display-authors=etal}}</ref> However, an exact determination of the cause of ASD has yet to be discovered and there probably is not one single genetic cause of any particular set of disorders, leading many researchers to believe that epigenetic mechanisms, such as genomic imprinting or epimutations, may play a major role.<ref name="Samaco">{{cite journal|title=Epigenetic overlap in autism-spectrum neurodevelopmental disorders: MECP2 deficiency causes reduced expression of UBE3A and GABRB3|journal=Human Molecular Genetics|volume=14|pages=483–492|date=2005|author=Samaco, R.C.|author2=Hogart, A.|author3=LaSalle, J.M.|last-author-amp=yes|pmid=15615769|issue=4|doi=10.1093/hmg/ddi045|pmc=1224722}}</ref><ref name="Jiang">{{cite journal|title=A mixed epigenetic/genetic model for oligogenic inheritance of autism with a limited role for UBE3A|journal=American Journal of Medical Genetics|volume=131|issue=1|pages=1–10|doi=10.1002/ajmg.a.30297 |date=2004|author=Jiang YH|author2=Sahoo T|author3=Michaelis RC|author4=Bercovich D|author5=Bressler J|author6=Kashork CD|author7=Liu Q|author8=Shaffer LG|author9=Schroer RJ|author10=Stockton DW|author11=Spielman RS|author12=Stevenson RE|author13=Beaudet AL|pmid=15389703}}</ref>
[[Epigenetic]] mechanisms can contribute to disease [[phenotype]]s. Epigenetic modifications include [[DNA cytosine methylation]] and post-translational modifications to [[histone]]s. These mechanisms contribute to regulating gene expression without changing the sequence of the DNA and may be influenced by exposure to environmental factors and may be heritable from parents.<ref name="Schanen"/> [[Rett syndrome]] and [[Fragile X syndrome]] (FXS) are single gene disorders related to ASD with overlapping symptoms that include deficient neurological development, impaired language and communication, difficulties in social interactions, and stereotyped hand gestures. It is not uncommon for a patient to be diagnosed with both ASD and Rett syndrome and/or FXS. Epigenetic regulatory mechanisms play the central role in pathogenesis of these two diseases.<ref name="Samaco"/><ref name="Lopez">{{cite journal|title=Further evidence for pigenetic influence of MECP2 in Rett, autism and Angelman's syndromes|journal=Clinical Genetics|volume=69|pages=23–25|date=2006|author=Lopez-Rangel, E.|author2=Lewis, M.E.|last-author-amp=yes|doi=10.1111/j.1399-0004.2006.00543c.x}}</ref><ref name="Hagerman">{{cite journal|title=Recent advances in fragile X: a model for autism and neurodegeneration|journal=Current Opinion in Psychiatry|volume=18|pages=490–496|date=2005|author=Hagerman, R.J.|author2=Ono, M.Y.|author3=Hagerman, P.J.|last-author-amp=yes|doi=10.1097/01.yco.0000179485.39520.b0|pmid=16639106|issue=5}}</ref> Rett syndrome is caused by a mutation in the gene that encodes [[methyl-CpG-binding protein]] ([[MECP2]]), one of the key epigenetic regulators of gene expression.<ref name="Amir">{{cite journal|title=Rett syndrome is caused by mutations in X-linked MECP2, encoding methyl-CpG-binding protein 2|journal=Nature Genetics|volume=23|pages=185–188|date=October 1999|pmid=10508514|doi=10.1038/13810|author=Amir, R.E.|author2=Van den Veyver, I.B.|author3=Wan, M.|author4=Tran, C.Q.|author5=Francke, U.|author6=Zoghbi, H.Y.|last-author-amp=yes|issue=2}}</ref> MeCP2 binds methylated cytosine residues in DNA and interacts with complexes that remodel chromatin into repressive structures.<ref name="Klose">{{cite journal|title=Genomic DNA methylation: the mark and its mediators|journal=Trends in Biochemical Sciences|volume=31|pages=89–97|date=2006|author=Klose, R.J.|author2=Bird, A.P.|last-author-amp=yes|doi=10.1016/j.tibs.2005.12.008|pmid=16403636|issue=2}}</ref><ref name="Kriaucionis">{{cite journal|title=DNA methylation and Rett syndrome|journal=Human Molecular Genetics|volume=12|issue=2|pages=R221–R227|date=2003|author=Kriaucionis, S.|author2=Bird, A.|last-author-amp=yes|doi=10.1093/hmg/ddg286|pmid=12928486}}</ref> On the other hand, FXS is caused by mutations that are both genetic and epigenetic. Expansion of the CGG repeat in the 5’-untranslated region of the [[FMR1]] genes leads to susceptibility of epigenetic silencing, leading to loss of gene expression.<ref name="Hagerman"/>
[[Genomic imprinting]] may also contribute to ASD. Genomic imprinting is another example of epigenetic regulation of gene expression. In this instance, the epigenetic modification(s) causes the offspring to express the maternal copy of a gene or the paternal copy of a gene, but not both. The imprinted gene is silenced through epigenetic mechanisms. Candidate genes and susceptibility alleles for autism are identified using a combination of techniques, including genome-wide and targeted analyses of allele sharing in sib-pairs, using association studies and transmission disequilibrium testing (TDT) of functional and/or positional candidate genes and examination of novel and recurrent cytogenetic aberrations. Results from numerous studies have identified several genomic regions known to be subject to imprinting, candidate genes, and gene-environment interactions. Particularly, chromosomes 15q and 7q appear to be epigenetic hotspots in contributing to ASD. Also, genes on the X chromosome may play an important role, as in Rett Syndrome.<ref name="Schanen"/>
==Chromosome 15== In humans, chromosome [[15q11-13]] is the location of a number of mutations that have been associated with Autism spectrum disorders (ASD).
===15q11-13 duplication=== [[Chromosome duplication|Duplications]] of 15q11-13 are associated with about 5% of patients with ASD<ref name="Schanen"/> and about 1% of patients diagnosed with classical Autism.<ref name="Hogart">{{cite journal|author=Samaco, R. C.|author2=Hogart, A.|author3=LaSalle, J. M.|last-author-amp=yes|title=Epigenetic overlap in autism-spectrum neurodevelopmental disorders: MECP2 deficiency causes reduced expression of UBE3A and GABRB3|journal=Human Molecular Genetics|volume=14|issue=4|pages=483–492|date=2005|pmid=15615769|doi=10.1093/hmg/ddi045|pmc=1224722}}</ref> 15q11-13 in humans contains a cluster of genetically [[imprinted gene]]s important for normal [[neurodevelopment]]. (Table 1) Like other genetically imprinted genes, the parent of origin determines the [[phenotype]]s associated with 15q11-13 duplications.<ref name="Cook">{{cite journal|author=Cook, E.H., Jr.|author2=Lindgren, V.|author3=Leventhal, B.L.|author4=Courchesne, R.|author5=Lincoln, A.|author6=Shulman, C.|author7=Lord, C.|author8=Courchesne, E.|last-author-amp=yes|title=Autism or atypical autism in maternally but not paternally derived proximal 15q duplication|journal=American Journal of Human Genetics|volume=60|pages=928–934|date=1997|pmid=9106540|issue=4|pmc=1712464}}</ref> "Parent of origin effects" cause gene expression to occur only from one of the two copies of [[allele]]s that individuals receive from their parents. (For example, [[MKRN3]] shows a parent of origin effect and is paternally imprinted. This means that only the MKRN3 allele received from the paternal side will be expressed.) Genes that are deficient in paternal or maternal 15q11-13 alleles result in [[Prader-Willi syndrome|Prader-Willi]] or [[Angelman syndrome]]s, respectively, and duplications in the maternal copy lead to a distinct condition that often includes autism. [[Overexpression]] of maternally imprinted genes is predicted to cause autism, which focuses attention to the maternally expressed genes on 15q11-13, although it is still possible that alterations in the expression of both imprinted and [[bilallelically]] expressed genes contribute to these disorders.<ref name="Chromosome">{{cite journal|author=Hogart, A.|title=Chromosome 15q11-13 duplication syndrome brain reveals epigenetic alteration in gene expression not predicted from copy number|journal=Journal of Medical Genetics|volume=46|issue=2|pages=86–93|date=2009|doi=10.1136/jmg.2008.061580|pmid=18835857|pmc=2634820}}</ref> The commonly duplicated region of chromosome 15 also includes paternally imprinted genes that can be considered candidates for ASD. (See Table 1)

Genes on 15q11-13 can be classified into three main categories: * '''GABA<sub>A</sub> receptor genes:''' Members of the GABA receptor family, especially GABRB3, are attractive candidate genes for Autism because of their function in the nervous system. Gabrb3 null mice exhibit behaviors consistent with autism<ref name="Klose"/> and multiple genetic studies have found significant evidence for association.<ref name="Kriaucionis"/> Furthermore, a significant decrease in abundance of GABRB3 has been reported in the brain of AS, AUT and RTT patients.<ref name="Pickles">{{cite journal|author=Pickles, A.|author2=Bolton, P.|author3=Macdonald, H.|author4=Bailey, A.|author5=Le Couteur, A.|author6=Sim, C.H.|author7=Rutter, M.|last-author-amp=yes|title=Latent-class analysis of recurrence risks for complex phenotypes with selection and measurement error: a twin and family history study of autism|journal=American Journal of Human Genetics|volume=57|issue=3|pages=717–726|date=1995|pmid=7668301|pmc=1801262}}</ref> Other GABA receptors residing on different chromosomes have also been associated with autism (e.g. GABRA4 and GABRB1 on chromosome 4p).<ref name="Ma">{{cite journal|author=Ma, D.Q.|author2=Whitehead, P.L.|author3=Menold, M.M.|author4=Martin, E.R.|author5=Ashley-Koch, A.E.|author6=Mei, H.|author7=Ritchie, M.D.|author8=Delong, G.R.|author9=Abramson, R.K.|author10=Wright, H.H.|title=Identification of significant association and gene – gene interaction of GABA receptor subunit genes in autism|journal=American Journal of Human Genetics|volume=77|pages=377–388|date=2005 |doi=10.1086/433195|pmid=16080114|issue=3|pmc=1226204|display-authors=etal}}</ref> * '''Maternally imprinted genes:''' There are two maternally imprinted genes in 15q11-13, UBE3A and ATP10A (Table 1) and both lie toward the [[centromeric]] end. Both these genes are important candidates for ASD. Significant decrease in UBE3A abundance has been observed in [[post mortem]] brain samples from patients with AUT, AS and RT.<ref name="Hogart"/> Patients with autism have also shown abnormalities in methylation of the UBE3A [[CpG island]].<ref name="Jiang" /> * '''Paternally imprinted genes:''' Most of the genes in 15q11-13 are paternally expressed. Gene expression analysis of paternally expressed imprinted genes has revealed that, in some cases excess of maternal 15q11-13 dosage can cause abnormal gene expression of the paternally expressed genes as well (even though the paternal 15q11-13 is normal).<ref name="duplication">{{cite journal|author=Hogart, A.|title=Chromosome 15q11-13 duplication syndrome brain reveals epigenetic alterations in gene expression not predicted from copy number|journal=Journal of Medical Genetics|volume=46|issue=2|pages=86–93|date=Feb 2009|doi=10.1136/jmg.2008.061580|display-authors=etal|pmid=18835857|pmc=2634820}}</ref> * '''Regulation of gene expression in 15q11-13:'''
Regulation of gene expression in the 15q11-13 is rather complex and involves a variety of mechanisms such as [[DNA methylation]], non-coding and [[anti-sense RNA]].<ref name="Nicholls">{{cite journal|author=Nicholls, R.D.|author2=Knepper, J.L.|last-author-amp=yes|title=Genome organization, function, and imprinting in Prader-Willi and Angelman syndromes|journal=Annu. Rev. Genom. Hum. Genet.|volume=2|pages=153–175|date=2001|doi=10.1146/annurev.genom.2.1.153|pmid=11701647}}</ref>
The imprinted genes of 15q11-13 are under the control of a common regulatory sequence, the [[imprinting control region]] (ICR). The ICR is a differentially methylated CpG island at the 5′ end of [[SNRPN]]. It is heavily methylated on the silent maternal allele and unmethylated on the active paternal allele.<ref name="duplication"/>
[[MeCP2]], which is a candidate gene for [[Rett syndrome]], has been shown to affect regulation of expression in 15q11-13. Altered (decreased) expression of UBE3A and GABRB3 is observed in MeCP2 deficient mice and ASD patients. This effect seems to happen without MeCP2 directly binding to the promoters of UBE3A and GABRB3. (Mechanism unknown)<ref name="Pickles"/> However, [[chromatin immunoprecipitation]] and [[bisulfite sequencing]] have demonstrated that MeCP2 binds to methylated CpG sites within GABRB3 and the [[promoter (genetics)|promoter]] of SNRPN/SNURF.<ref name="Hogart"/>
Furthermore, [[homologous pairing|homologous]] 15q11-13 pairing in neurons that is disrupted in RTT and autism patients, has been shown to depend on MeCP2.<ref name="gabaa">{{cite journal|author=Hogart, A.|title=15q11-13 gabaa receptor genes are normally biallelically expressed in brain yet are subject to epigenetic dysregulation in autism spectrum disorders|journal=Human Molecular Genetics|volume=16|issue=6|pages=691–703|date=2007 |pmid=17339270 |doi=10.1093/hmg/ddm014|pmc=1934608|display-authors=etal}}</ref> Combined, these data suggest a role for MeCP2 in the regulation of imprinted and biallelic genes in 15q11-13. However, evidently it does not play a role in the maintenance of imprinting.<ref name="Hogart"/>
==Chromosome 7== * Imprinting and epigenetics of [[Chromosome 7 (human)|chromosome 7q]] in ASD
A genome-wide scan approach has revealed possible linkage of ASDs and autism to numerous chromosomes. These linkage studies initially implicated the long arm of chromosome 7, and sequence analyses specifically targeted two susceptibility loci at the regions of 7q21.3 and 7q32.2.<ref name="Schanen"/> Parent-of-origin linkage modeling identified the imprinted gene cluster 7q21.3, which includes two paternally expressed genes, two maternally expressed genes, and one preliminarily determined maternally expressed gene, as summarized in the table below. (Table 2)

[[DLX5]] and [[DLX2]] directly regulate expression of [[glutamic acid decarboxylase]], the enzyme that produces the [[neurotransmitter]] [[GABA]]. Conclusive evidence of autism susceptibility due to [[novel sequence]] variants of these genes has yet to be clearly identified, however. To date, these loci cannot be definitely associated with autism, though their connection with Mecp2 via regulation suggests the epigenetic effects should be re-evaluated.<ref name="Schanen"/>

==X Chromosome==
There is a definite [[gender bias]] in the distribution of ASD. There are about four times as many affected males across the ASD population. Even when patients with mutations in [[X-linked gene]]s ([[MECP2]] and [[FMR1]]) are excluded, the gender bias remains. However, when only looking at patients with the most severe cognitive impairment, the gender bias is not as extreme. While the most obvious conclusion is that an X-linked gene of major effect is involved in contributing to ASD, the mechanism appears to be much more complex and perhaps epigenetic in origin.<ref name="Schanen"/>
Based on the results of a study on females with [[Turner syndrome]], a hypothesis involving epigenetic mechanisms was proposed to help describe the gender bias of ASD. Turner syndrome patients have only one X chromosome which can be either maternal or paternal in origin. When 80 females with [[monosomy]] X were tested for measures of social cognition, the patients with a paternally derived X chromosome performed better than those with a maternally derived X chromosome. Males have only one X chromosome, derived from their mother. If a gene on the paternal X chromosome confers improved social skills, males are deficient in the gene. This could explain why males are more likely to be diagnosed with ASD.<ref name="Skuse">{{cite journal|author=Skuse, D.H.|author2=James, R.S.|author3=Bishop, D.V.|author4=Coppin, B.|author5=Dalton, P.|author6=Aamodt-Leeper, G.|author7=Bacarese-Hamilton, M.|author8=Creswell, C.|author9=McGurk, R.|author10=Jacobs, P.A.|last-author-amp=yes|title=Evidence from Turner's syndrome of an imprinted X-linked locus affecting cognitive function|journal=Nature|volume=387|pages=705–708|date=1997|doi=10.1038/42706|pmid=9192895|issue=6634|bibcode=1997Natur.387..705S}}</ref>
In the proposed model, the candidate gene is silenced on the maternal copy of the X chromosome. Thus, males do not express this gene and are more susceptible to subsequent impairments in social and communication skills. Females, on the other hand, are more resistant to ASD.<ref name="Imprinting">{{cite journal|author=Skuse, D. H.|title=Imprinting, the X-chromosome, and the male brain: explaining sex differences in the liability to autism|journal=Pediatric Research|volume=47|pages=9–16|date=2000|doi=10.1203/00006450-200001000-00006|pmid=10625077|issue=1|doi-access=free}}</ref><ref name="abd">{{cite journal|author=El Abd, S.|author2=Patton, M.A.|author3=Turk, J.|author4=Hoey, H.|author5=Howlin, P.|last-author-amp=yes |title=Social, communicational, and behavioral deficits associated with ring X turner syndrome|journal=American Journal of Medical Genetics|volume=88|pages=510–516|date=1999|doi=10.1002/(SICI)1096-8628(19991015)88:5<510::AID-AJMG14>3.0.CO;2-Z|pmid=10490708|issue=5}}</ref><ref name="Telvi">{{cite journal|author=Telvi, L.|author2=Lebbar, A.|author3=Del Pino, O.|author4=Barbet, J.P.|author5=Chaussain, J.L.|last-author-amp=yes|title=45,X/46,XY mosaicism: report of 27 cases|journal=Pediatrics|volume=104|pages=304–308|date=1999|doi=10.1542/peds.104.2.304|pmid=10429013|issue=2 Pt 1}}</ref><ref name="Donnelly">{{cite journal|author=Donnelly, S.L.|author2=Wolpert, C.M.|author3=Menold, M.M.|author4=Bass, M.P.|author5=Gilbert, J.R.|author6=Cuccaro, M.L.|author7=Delong, G.R.|author8=Pericak-Vance, M.A.|last-author-amp=yes|title=Female with autistic disorder and monosomy X (Turner syndrome): parent-of-origin effect of the X chromosome|journal=American Journal of Medical Genetics|volume=96|pages=312–316|date=2000|doi=10.1002/1096-8628(20000612)96:3<312::AID-AJMG16>3.0.CO;2-8|pmid=10898907|issue=3}}</ref> Recently a cluster of imprinted genes on the mouse X chromosome was discovered; the paternal allele was expressed while the female copy was imprinted and silenced.<ref name="Davies">{{cite journal|title=Xlr3b is a new imprinted candidate for X-linked parent-of-origin effects on cognitive function in mice|journal=Nature Genetics |volume=37|pages=625–629|date=2005|author=William Davies|author2=Anthony Isles|author3=Rachel Smith|author4=Delicia Karunadasa|author5=Doreen Burrmann|author6=Trevor Humby|author7=Obah Ojarikre|author8=Carol Biggin|author9=David Skuse|author10=Paul Burgoyne|author11=Lawrence Wilkinson|last-author-amp=yes|doi=10.1038/ng1577|pmid=15908950|issue=6}}</ref><ref name="Raefski">{{cite journal|author=Raefski, A.S.|author2=O’Neill, M. J.|last-author-amp=yes|title=Identification of a cluster of X-linked imprinted genes in mice|journal=Nat. Genet.|volume=37|pages=620–624|date=2005|doi=10.1038/ng1567|pmid=15908953|issue=6}}</ref> Further studies are aimed at discovering whether these genes contribute directly to behavior and whether the counterpart genes in humans are imprinted.<ref name="Schanen"/>
==The Link to Rett Syndrome== Epigenetic alterations of the methylation states of genes such as [[MECP2]] and [[EGR2]] have been shown to play a role in autism and autism spectrum disorders. MECP2 abnormalities have been shown to lead to a wide range of phenotypic variability and molecular complexities.<ref name="Percy">{{cite journal |last1=Percy |first1=Alan K. |title=Rett Syndrome: Exploring the Autism Link |journal=Archives of Neurology |date=1 August 2011 |volume=68 |issue=8 |pages=985 |doi=10.1001/archneurol.2011.149 |pmid=21825235 |pmc=3674963}}</ref> These variabilities have led to the exploration of the clinical and molecular convergence between [[Rett syndrome]] and autism.<ref name="Percy"/>
[[Sleeping disorder|Sleeping]] and [[language disorder|language impairments]], seizures, and developmental timing are common in both autism and Rett syndrome (RTT). Because of these phenotypic similarities, there has been research into the specific genetic similarities between these two pervasive developmental disorders. MECP2 has been identified as the predominant gene involved in RTT. It has also been shown that the regulation of the MECP2 gene expression has been implicated in autism.<ref name="Nagarajan">{{cite journal|date=2004|title=Multiple pathways regulate MeCP2 expression in normal brain development and exhibit defects in autism-spectrum disorders|journal=Human Molecular Genetics|volume=13|pages=629–639|author=Samaco RC|author2=Nagarajan RP|author3=Braunschweig D|author4=LaSalle JM|doi=10.1093/hmg/ddh063|pmid=14734626|issue=6|doi-access=free}}</ref> Rett syndrome brain samples and autism brain samples show immaturity of [[Dendritic spine|dendrite spines]] and reduction of cell-body size due to errors in coupled regulation between MECP2 and EGR2.<ref name="Armstrong">{{cite journal|date=1995|title=Selective dendritic alterations in the cortex of Rett syndrome|journal=J Neuropathol Exp Neurol|volume=54|pages=195–201|author=Armstrong D|author2=Dunn JK|author3=Antalffy B|author4=Trivedi R|doi=10.1097/00005072-199503000-00006|pmid=7876888|issue=2}}</ref> However, because of the multigene involvement in autism, the MECP2 gene has only been identified as a vulnerability factor in autism.<ref name="Shahbazian">{{cite journal|title= Rett Syndrome and MeCP2: Linking Epigenetics and Neuronal Function|journal=American Journal of Human Genetics|volume=71|issue=6|pages=1259–1272|date=2002|author=Shahbazian, M.D.|author2=Zoghbi, H.Y.|doi= 10.1086/345360|pmid= 12442230|pmc= 378559}}</ref> The most current model illustrating MECP2 is known as the transcriptional activator model.
Another potential molecular convergence involves the [[EGR2|early growth response gene-2]] (EGR2).<ref name="Percy"/> EGR2 is the only gene in the EGR family that is restricted to the central nervous system and is involved in [[Cerebral cortex#Development|cerebral development]] and [[synaptic plasticity]].<ref name="Percy"/> EGR2 expression has been shown to decrease in the cortexes of individuals with both autism and RTT.<ref name="Swanberg">{{cite journal|title=Reciprocal co-regulation of EGR2 and MECP2 is disrupted in Rett syndrome and autism|journal=Human Molecular Genetics|date=2009|volume=18|issue=3|pages=525–534|author=Swanberg SE|author2=Nagarajan RP|author3=Peddada S|author4= Yasui DH|author5=LaSalle JM|pmid=19000991|doi=10.1093/hmg/ddn380|pmc=2638799}}</ref> MECP2 expression has also been shown to decrease in individuals with RTT and autism. MECP2 and EGR2 have been shown to regulate each other during [[Neural development|neuronal maturation]].<ref name="Swanberg"/> A role for the dysregulation of the activity-dependent EGR2/MECP2 pathway in RTT and autism has been proposed.<ref name="Swanberg"/> Further molecular linkages are being examined; however, the exploration of MECP2 and EGR2 have provided a common link between RTT, autism, and similarities in phenotypic expression.
